revised_title: Spectroscopic Observations of the Eclipse of the Sun in 1868
tldr: In 1868, Captain C. T. Haig observed the total solar eclipse using a hand-spectroscope provided by the Royal Society. He noticed two red flames with distinct spectra, which had two broad bright bands. The spectra of the flames were much more brilliant than the spectrum of the sun's corona, even though the flames appeared faint to the naked eye. This observation provided valuable insights into the nature of the sun's corona and the behavior of light during a total solar eclipse.
